description: Issues that have been reported as service requests. Location is submitted via lat/long or address or address_id

service_request_id.description: Unique ID of the service request created.

status.description: Current status of the service request.

status_notes.description: Explanation of why status was changed to current state or more details on current status than conveyed with status alone.

service_name.description: The human readable name of the service request type.

service_code.description: The unique identifier for the service request type

description.description: A full description of the request or report submitted.

agency_responsible.description: Agency responsible for fulfilling or otherwise addressing the service request.

service_notice.description: Information about the action expected to fulfill the request or otherwise address the information reported.

requested_datetime.description: Date and time when the service request was made.

updated_datetime.description: Date and time when the service request was last modified. For requests with status=closed, this will be the date the request was closed.

expected_datetime.description: The date and time when the service request can be expected to be fulfilled. This may be based on a service-specific service level agreement.

address.description: Human readable address or description of location. This should be provided from most specific to most general geographic unit, eg address number or cross streets, street name, neighborhood/district, city/town/village, county, postal code.

address_id.description: Internal address ID used by a jurisdictions master address repository or other addressing system.

zipcode.description: postal code for the location of the service request. (Redundant and field might be removed as it should be part of adress string)

media_url.description: URL to media associated with the request, eg an image. A convention for parsing media from this URL has yet to be established, so currently it will be done on a case by case basis much like Twitter.com does. For example, if a jurisdiction accepts photos submitted via Twitpic.com, then clients can parse the page at the Twitpic URL for the image given the conventions of Twitpic.com. This could also be a URL to a media RSS feed where the clients can parse for media in a more structured way.
